title: Mayoral candidate Jones has the appropriate assertiveness
text:
Close Jerry Naunheim Jr. 
WEDNESDAY, JAN. 25, 2017 - St. Louis mayoral candidate Tishaura Jones speaks at a forum Wednesday with other candidates at the Thomas Dunn Learning Center, 3113 Gasconade Street. ©Photo by Jerry Naunheim Jr. Mayoral candidate Jones has the appropriate assertiveness Feb 22, 2017 ( … ) Jerry Naunheim Jr. 
WEDNESDAY, JAN. 25, 2017 - St. Louis mayoral candidate Tishaura Jones speaks at a forum Wednesday with other candidates at the Thomas Dunn Learning Center, 3113 Gasconade Street. ©Photo by Jerry Naunheim Jr. 
The Post-Dispatch endorsement of Antonio French for mayor (Feb. 19) said he needs to modulate his tone. It attacks Tishaura Jones, an opponent, for “consistently bad temperament and judgment.” 
My translation: When a man speaks with assertiveness, that’s OK even if he should modulate a bit. When it’s a woman, the male ego is annoyed by a strong push back that objectively is just assertiveness. 
I’m a 73-year-old white male who mentored Jones when she was an outstanding executive trainee at Cardinal Glennon Children’s Hospital, part of SSM Health. In that organization, founded and run by women for decades, we understood the difference. Effective leadership often requires assertiveness to achieve a goal. 
The Post-Dispatch interpretation of the actions of these two African-American leaders doesn’t reconcile as even-handed on gender. Jones holds her own with leadership assertiveness and demonstrated results. 
Steven M. Barney • St. Louis Tags
